PAGE.TITLE: Matrix Multiplication
PAGE.DESCRIPTION: Matrices are enormously important in advanced mathematics and these mathematical objects appear in a range of different fields. It is thus important that you understand how to add and multiply matrices. The exercises on this page should consolidate your ability to multiply matrices.

EXAMPLE.QUESTION: Calculate the following product of matrices $$ \left( \begin{matrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} e & f \\ g & h \end{matrix} \right) $$

Only one of the following matrix multiplications can be performed. Can you explain which one it is: $$ \left( \begin{matrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} e \\ f \end{matrix} \right) \qquad \qquad \qquad \left( \begin{matrix} e \\ f \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{matrix} \right) $$
EXAMPLE.SOLUTION: When multiplying rectangular matrices the number of columns in the first matrix must be equal to the number of rows in the second matrix. Consequently the following matrix multiplication is possible: $$ \left( \begin{matrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} e \\ f \end{matrix} \right) = \left( \begin{matrix} ae + bf \\ ce + df \end{matrix} \right) $$ But the following matrix multiplication cannot be performed: $$ \left( \begin{matrix} e \\ f \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{matrix} \right) $$

EXERCISE.TITLE: Exercise 1
EXERCISE.PROBLEMS:
Write down which of the following matrix multiplication problems it is possible to do. If the multiplication problem is possible do the matrix multiplication.
$$ \left( \begin{matrix} 6 & 3 \\ 2 & -1 \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} 3 & 2 \\ -4 & 8 \end{matrix} \right) $$
$$ \left( \begin{matrix} -1 & 2 & 1 \\ 8 & -3 & 5 \\ 11 & 2 & 6 \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} 3 & 2 & -1 \\ 5 & 3 & 2 \\ 6 & 1 & 4 \end{matrix} \right) $$
$$ \left( \begin{matrix} -8 & 5 & 2 & -3 \\ 1 & -1 & 6 & 7 \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} 3 & 5 \\ 2 & 2 \\ 6 & 1 \\ 8 & -4 \end{matrix} \right) $$
$$ \left( \begin{matrix} 3 & 5 \\ 2 & 2 \\ 6 & 1 \\ 8 & -4 \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} -8 & 5 & 2 & -3 \\ 1 & -1 & 6 & 7 \end{matrix} \right) $$
$$ \left( \begin{matrix} 6 & 3 \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} 3 \\ -4 \end{matrix} \right) $$
$$ \left( \begin{matrix} 6 & 3 \\ \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} 3 & 2 \\ -4 & 8 \end{matrix} \right) $$
$$ \left( \begin{matrix} 6 \\ 3 \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} 3 & 2 \\ -4 & 8 \end{matrix} \right) $$
$$ \left( \begin{matrix} 3 & 2 \\ -4 & 8 \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} 6 \\ 3 \end{matrix} \right) $$

EXERCISE.TITLE: Adding the transpose
EXERCISE.PROBLEMS:
If a matrix has a small superscript T above it that means I would like you to transpose the matrix before doing the matrix multiplication. If by contrast you have a matrix product such as $(\mathbf{AB})^T$ that means I would like you to transpose the matrix you get from the mutltiplication.
$$ \left( \begin{matrix} 6 & 3 \\ 2 & -1 \end{matrix} \right)^T \left( \begin{matrix} 3 & 2 \\ -4 & 8 \end{matrix} \right) $$
$$ \left( \begin{matrix} 6 & 3 \\ 2 & -1 \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} 3 & 2 \\ -4 & 8 \end{matrix} \right)^T $$
$$ \left( \begin{matrix} 6 & 3 \\ 2 & -1 \end{matrix} \right)^T \left( \begin{matrix} 3 & 2 \\ -4 & 8 \end{matrix} \right)^T $$
$$ \left( \begin{matrix} 3 & 2 \\ -4 & 8 \end{matrix} \right)^T \left( \begin{matrix} 6 & 3 \\ 2 & -1 \end{matrix} \right)^T $$
$$ \left[ \left( \begin{matrix} 6 & 3 \\ 2 & -1 \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} 3 & 2 \\ -4 & 8 \end{matrix} \right) \right]^T $$
Given the results you obtained in the above exercises, which of the following equalities is correct for any pair of matrices $\mathbf{A}$ and $\mathbf{B}$. $$ \mathbf{A}^T \mathbf{B} = \mathbf{A}\mathbf{B} \qquad (\mathbf{A}\mathbf{B})^T = \mathbf{A}^T\mathbf{B}^T \qquad (\mathbf{A}\mathbf{B})^T = \mathbf{B}^T \mathbf{A}^T \qquad (\mathbf{A}\mathbf{B})^T = \mathbf{B} \mathbf{A}^T $$
